title: Setting up the navigation bar
text:
The navigation bar is the main location where


Code
---
project:
1  type: website

2website:
3  title: "Palmer Penguins"
4  page-navigation: true
5  page-footer:
      center: |
        ![](palmerpenguins.png){width=20%}
      right: Palmer Penguins adapted by Ann Wells
6  navbar:
7    background:  "#ceb6db" #"#d1dbe8" #"#013377"
    foreground: "#350d56"
8    logo: JAX_LOGO_no_words.png
9    left:
      - text: "Home"
        file: index.qmd
      - text: "Who are the penguins?"
        href: 01_who_are_the_penguins.qmd

10format:
  html:
    theme: cerulean
    highlight-style: textmate
    css: styles.css
    toc: true
    

11editor: visual
---



1

This determines the type of output you want.

2

This is needed to establish the structure of the website.

3

This is the title of your website and it will show in the upper left corner.

4

page-navigation is not necessary but it will add next and previous page buttons to the bottom of your site if you have sidebar navigation.

5

The page footer will allow you to add links, authorship, logos, copyrights, etc. and these will display on all pages of the site.

6

The navbar is needed to establish website structure.

7

background and foreground will change the navigation bar color and the text color of the navigation bar.

8

logo will add an image to the left of the website title.

9

left establishes the directory structure on the left side of the navigation bar and subsequent drop down menus. If you add right then that will establish the directory structure or links to the right side of the navigation bar.

10

format establishes the desired output, color style of the output, the highlight style when the cursor hovers over links, set the table of contents to true or false globally, and locate the css file for specialized styling.

11

Allows the ability to visualize the formatting without rendering the file or website.

title: Hosting Your Website
text:
Hosting on the carterdev server is great for internal projects but requires vpn access. To do this follow these steps:
1. Go to terminal in your RStudio or VScode IDE.
2. Copy over _site folder using this command:


Code
## remove echo if copying code
echo scp -r _site shortname@carterdev.jax.org:/srv/shiny-server/foldername


scp -r _site shortname@carterdev.jax.org:/srv/shiny-server/foldername


3. push enter and you will be asked to enter your password. This is your JAX password.
4. Files should start copying over and you’re done!
To access the site you will use the following url:
http://carterdev.jax.org:3838/foldername/_site
where foldername correpsonds to your project name.

title: Hosting Your Website
text:
Hosting on Goggle Cloud Platform
Hosting on the GCP will require a service ticket, which can be accessed here
To request a new project you will need these items:
1. Request type Create a new GCP project
2. Research project name (they list the naming convention on the request)
3. Billing information
4. Environment (Development, staging, production)






Note



This can be discussed with RIT before submission, if it’s not clear which to choose.


5. User Access






Note



This is where you will list everyone that you want to have access to your project. The people listed here also need to have a GCP account.


There are two avenues for GCP hosted site: public and private. In both cases RIT needs to be contacted first and the instructions above need to be performed, however, you will need to know if you want a public or private website because they will need to set up your project differently to accomodate for the different levels of security.
For public sites:
If you want to host your site publicly then you will ask that RIT set up a project that can be seen publicly but remains private until you are ready. This means that until you are ready to share your site no one will have access. Once you are ready to make your site public contact RIT again and they will change the setting to public and the url will be:
https://storage.googleapis.com/bucketname/index.html
To fill your project with your website you will do two things:

Create a bucket within the project.
Copy over all of the material that is inside your _site folder but not the folder itself into the bucket.
Done!

For private sites: Private sites are more complicated and take longer to set up (over a month!). Per RIT, “In general a Identity-Aware Proxy (IAP) with a load balancer can do a private access to a GCP hosted site”. However, if a private site is absolutely needed then they are happy to do so. Once that is complete then you would follow the same steps as above. The only people than can access your private site are JAX employees.






Important



In the cases of hosting on the carterdev server or privately on the GCP, no one outside of JAX will have access. This is something I have currently asked about to find options and solutions. Hosting publicly allows anyone with the url to see your website.

title: Building websites for Data Dissemination, Reproducibility, and Transparency
text:
It’s easier to talk with collaborators and share results in an intuitive way.
It’s easier to understand the outcome of an experiment and organize data in a way that will be accessible years after the project is complete.
The websites don’t require traditional biologists to understand your code but empower them to understand the steps of analysis that have been taken to arrive at an outcome creating richer discussions.
At the end of a project they can easily be publicly hosted for other researchers to investigate the entire analysis that was completed, not just what was presented in the accompanying journal article.

title: Setting up the page yaml
text:
Each page within your website will have its own yaml information at the top. A yaml section is required, however, no line of code is necessary within the yaml. If the yaml is empty then the page will default to the specifications set in the _quarto.yml.
The page yaml can make each page’s style unique. There you can specify how you visualize code, images, the table of contents, etc. Below is a simple yaml. We will create a yaml for a page later.


Code
---
title: "The Palmer Penguins Data"
1lightbox: true
format:
  html:
    code-tools: 
2      source: true
3      toggle: true
4    code-fold: true
---



1

Lightbox allows you to click on any output image and it will show a larger image.

2

source set to true will allow anyone to copy the source code for a page in the upper right corner of the page.

3

toggle will create a dropdown menu at the top right corner for code and give options for whatever code you want to show.

4

code-fold will allow you to show code for each output throughout your page.

title: Establishing the Bones of a Website
text:
There are only a few steps to build the bones of a website.

Open RStudio
Click File and then New Project.




Adapted from quarto.org



Click Quarto website.




Adapted from quarto.org



Pick a name for your project and choose where to save it. Choose knitr as your engine and check all three boxes.



Click create project and you should see this:



To preview website click the build tab in the upper right quadrant or type quarto preview –render all –no-watch-inputs –no-browse in the console.





Open Visual Studio Code
push shift + command + p to open up the VS code panel



Type Quarto: Create project and choose website project



Choose where you want to store your project and click new folder to name your project. Then click choose Project Directory. You should see these files below:



Type quarto preview –render all –no-watch-inputs –no-browse in bash in the terminal to preview the website. Push command and click the link list to preview the website.

title: Quarto vs. Rmarkdown
text:
Quarto is the new rmarkdown. It isn’t much different as far as syntax, if you are familiar with Rmarkdown; however, Rmarkdown requires several packages to run and several packages to create different types of documents.



Adapted from Mine Cetinkaya Rundel’s hello-quarto presentation


On the other hand, quarto is both agnostic and a singular package. This means that quarto does not require RStudio or R to run and can utilize files from multiple coding languages. Additionally, quarto only requires quarto to create multiple document types, streamlining the dissemination process.



Artwork by @allison_horst Adapted from Mine Cetinkaya Rundel’s hello-quarto presentation





Artwork by @allison_horst Adapted from Mine Cetinkaya Rundel’s hello-quarto presentation


Quarto also lets you organize your files into folders, which allows for better organization of different data analyses within a project while Rmarkdown required all .rmd files be placed in the primary directory.
Rmarkdown will be maintained indefinitely; however, no new features will be developed. Quarto is the new documentation package and will continue to be developed and improved upon for the foreseeable future. All feature requests can be made here and documentation for current features can be found here





Adapted from Mine Cetinkaya Rundel’s hello-quarto presentation

text:
---
title: "The Palmer Penguins Data"
lightbox: true
format:
  html:
    code-tools: 
      source: true
      toggle: true
    code-fold: true
---

```{r}
#| output: false

source("global.R")
```

## The **palmerpenguins** package

This package contains two datasets:

1.  Here, we’ll focus on a curated subset of the raw data in the package named `penguins`, which can serve as an out-of-the-box alternative to [`datasets::iris`](https://rdrr.io/r/datasets/iris.html).

2.  The raw data, accessed from the [Environmental Data Initiative](https://environmentaldatainitiative.org/) (see full data citations below), is also available as [`palmerpenguins::penguins_raw`](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/penguins_raw.html).

The curated [`palmerpenguins::penguins`](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/penguins.html) dataset contains 8 variables (n = 344 penguins). You can read more about the variables by typing [`?penguins`](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/penguins.html).

## Culmen measurements

What are culmen length & depth? The culmen is “the upper ridge of a bird’s beak” (definition from Oxford Languages). In the simplified `penguins` subset, culmen length and depth have been updated to variables named `bill_length_mm` and `bill_depth_mm`.

For this penguin data, the bill/culmen length and depth are measured as shown below (thanks Kristen Gorman for clarifying!):

![Artwork by @allison_horst](culmen_depth.png)

## Installation


```{r, echo=FALSE}
install.packages("palmerpenguins")

```

```{r}
library(palmerpenguins)
library(tidyverse)
data(package = 'palmerpenguins')
```

1.  load library
2.  load palmerpenguin dataset

## The Data

The [`palmerpenguins::penguins`](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/penguins.html) data contains 333 complete cases, with 19 missing values.

```{r}
library(dplyr)
glimpse(penguins)
```

The [`palmerpenguins::penguins`](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/reference/penguins.html) data contains 333 complete cases, with 19 missing values.

```{r}
visdat::vis_dat(penguins)
```






Warning



Make sure to create a global.R file with all of the packages needed for the website and to assign the data of interest.


This is the code that should be placed in the global.R file


Code
library(here)
library(palmerpenguins)
library(tidyverse)    
data(package = 'palmerpenguins')

penguins <- penguins








Note



If you change code-fold to show then your code will default to visible but can be hidden still. If you change code-fold to true then your code will default to hidden but is visible with a click.


Continue adding pages to the yaml and creating more pages from the penguin practice website.
